summary: This document is a chain of emails from December 2020 between U.S. prosecutors in the Southern District of New York (SDNY) and a DOJ Attaché at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, coordinating a legal response to Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed bail application. The discussion focuses on obtaining evidence and official statements from French authorities to counter Maxwell's arguments regarding the impossibility of her extradition from France to the U.S.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the SDNY criminal case. Her defense team filed a renewed bail application and a supplemental report from a French expert arguing against the possibility of extradition from France.

persons.name: John McNeil
persons.context: Referred to as the head of the litigation group at OIA (Office of International Affairs). His approval was sought regarding a statement about anticipatory extradition waivers.

connections.description: McNeil, as a DOJ litigation supervisor, was involved in reviewing and providing guidance on legal arguments related to Maxwell's bail application and the issue of extradition from France.

events.title: Maxwell Files Renewed Bail Application
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed a renewed bail application, which included a legal opinion on French law and a proposed extradition waiver as exhibits.

events.title: Defeat of Bail Proposal
events.description: An email congratulates the recipient on defeating a bail proposal, likely referring to a successful opposition by prosecutors to Maxwell's bail application.

events.title: Scheduled Meeting with Paris Prosecutor's Office
events.description: A DOJ Attaché scheduled a meeting with the Paris Prosecutor's Office, later pushed to January 7th, 2021, regarding the case.

locations: One St. Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Prosecutors were actively gathering evidence to oppose Ghislaine Maxwell's December 2020 bail application, which argued she could not be extradited from France.

French authorities, including the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), provided a letter stating France does not extradite its nationals outside the EU, including to the U.S., and has never derogated from that principle.
The U.S. State Department and DOJ's Office of International Affairs (OIA) researched and confirmed they were unaware of any instance where France extradited a French citizen to the United States.

The correspondence references two specific past cases where U.S. extradition requests for French nationals (Hans Peterson and an individual named Tchikaya) were refused by France on grounds of nationality.
The legal debate included the validity of 'anticipatory waivers of extradition,' with U.S. officials seeking to rebut the defense's claim that such a waiver from Maxwell would be binding in France.
